info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades final game 1.

(1, 1).clue: In the 2006 world title match, the challenger accused the champ of consulting a computer during visits to this room

(2, 1).clue: Some small beach birds are called peeps instead of these "pipers"

(3, 1).clue: Take advantage, "make ____ while the sun shines"

(4, 1).clue: It's the gradual accustoming of a child to take nourishment other than by nursing

(5, 1).clue: This river enters Idaho through the Palisades Reservoir on the Wyoming border

(6, 1).clue: 2013's "20 Feet from Stardom" is about women in this musical profession

(1, 2).clue: Aron Nimzovich once jumped on a table & screamed, "Why must I lose to this idiot!"--how like a GM, one of these

(2, 2).clue: There's a reptile in the name of this small, wild pigeon known for its cooing

(3, 2).clue: No way, no how, "not for all the tea in ____"

(4, 2).clue: To be "tied" to these even though someone is grown up means to still be controlled by a parent

(5, 2).clue: Vermont's lowest point is 95 feet above sea level on the shore of this lake

(6, 2).clue: "Religulous", featuring this atheistic host of HBO's "Real Time", has just a bit of an agenda

(1, 3).clue: Some of our champions know how this champion felt when he lost a 1997 match to IBM's Deep Blue computer

(2, 3).clue: Though the emu is taller, this relative is the heaviest bird in Australia

(4, 3).clue: From a Germanic word for "hatching", it's a large group of kids from one family

(5, 3).clue: This Rockies ridge splits the waters of the western U.S. into westward & eastward flowing

(6, 3).clue: Emily Stagg, S-T-A-G-G, is one of the stars of this 2002 film

(1, 4).clue: A 1978 match saw claims that this type of 16-letter "beyond the mind" expert was using telepathy to confuse 1 player

(2, 4).clue: Made popular by the movie "Happy Feet", this species was named for the wife of a French explorer

(3, 4).clue: From Ben Franklin:"Three may keep a secret, if two of them are ____"

(4, 4).clue: Infant wrappers mentioned in the King James version of Luke 2

(5, 4).clue: The snowy dome of this tallest volcano in the lower 48 states is often shrouded in clouds

(6, 4).clue: He directed "The Thin Blue Line" & the 2013 Donald Rumsfeld portrait "The Unknown Known"

(1, 5).clue: Cosmo selected this 22-year-old Norwegian, the new world champ, as one of its Sexiest Men of 2013

(2, 5).clue: All the little birdies go tweet, tweet, tweet, because they have this vocal organ, also a name for a panpipe

(3, 5).clue: From Proverbs 11, "He that troubleth his own house shall ____ ____ ____"

(4, 5).clue: Where did the years go? Time to fill out a FAFSA form to help junior do this

(5, 5).clue: Pasca, a Native American word for bread, gave this Gulf Coast city its name

(6, 5).clue: "Harlan County, USA" from 1976 marched with striking coal miners in this state

(1, 1).clue: In "Gorboduc", one of England's earliest plays in this genre, Porrex kills his brother; then their mother kills him

(2, 1).clue: Cerumen is the medical name for this, so be careful with the Q-tips

(3, 1).clue: The body of this Russian leader has been on display in Moscow since his death in 1924

(5, 1).clue: This Chrissie Hynde band covered The Persuaders' "A Thin Line Between Love & Hate"

(1, 2).clue: Thomas Kyd helped establish the unrhyming form called this verse on the English stage

(2, 2).clue: Doctors use this 5-letter term for swelling or bloating in the body due to an excess build-up of fluid

(3, 2).clue: Tell T.C. & Rick to keep it down!  It's time for this TV show whose theme is heard here

(5, 2).clue: Heroin addiction is a theme of "Hateful", a tune on this band's album "London Calling"

(6, 2).clue: This 11-letter part of a funeral home will really burn you up

(1, 3).clue: In John Lyly's 1595 play "The Woman in the Moon", shepherds ask nature to create this first woman of Greek myth

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a chromosome chart on the monitor.)  Charted here, a baby typically receives 23 pairs of chromosomes, 1 of each copied from each parent, but when there's an extra copy of chromosome 21, this condition is the result

(3, 3).clue: This Ohio-based company has more than 2,400 stores, including Ralphs & Dillons, in 31 states

(5, 3).clue: While serving in the Army during WWI, Irving Berlin was inspired to write the song "Oh! How I Hate To" do this

(6, 3).clue: Expensive gasoline, or a sum above nominal value

(1, 4).clue: This author of "Every Man in His Humour" was apparently out of humor when he stabbed a man to death in 1598

(2, 4).clue: It might ring a bell that ringing in the ears is known medically by this 8-letter name

(3, 4).clue: For negotiating an Arab-Israeli truce, this U.N. diplomat became the first African-American to win a Nobel Peace Prize

(4, 4).correct response: the end of the Vietnam War

(5, 4).clue: This Joan Jett & The Blackhearts hit was the basis for "Waiting All Day For Sunday Night", the "SNF" theme song

(6, 4).clue: This arch separates the stage from another new element, the auditorium

(1, 5).clue: Ian McKellen calls this author's "Edward II" "perhaps the first drama ever written with a homosexual hero"

(2, 5).clue: From the Greek for "narrow", it's a narrowing of a duct or canal, especially the spinal canal

(3, 5).clue: In a Whitman poem, this 3-word title precedes "Blow! Bugles! Blow!"

(4, 5).correct response: the ratification of the Bill of Rights

(5, 5).clue: This 2010 Gucci Mane song title rhymes with a popular sports drink

(6, 5).clue: Post-dinner convivial meeting for drinking & intellectual conversation in ancient Greece

(0, 0).clue: 1 of the 2 movies in the last 30 years, one a drama & one a comedy, to win Oscars for Best Actor & Best Actress
